prob_desc_notes: NoteThe first interesting number is equal to $$$9$$$.
prob_desc_description: Let's define $$$S(x)$$$ to be the sum of digits of number $$$x$$$ written in decimal system. For example, $$$S(5) = 5$$$, $$$S(10) = 1$$$, $$$S(322) = 7$$$.We will call an integer $$$x$$$ interesting if $$$S(x + 1) < S(x)$$$. In each test you will be given one integer $$$n$$$. Your task is to calculate the number of integers $$$x$$$ such that $$$1 \le x \le n$$$ and $$$x$$$ is interesting.
prob_desc_output_spec: Print $$$t$$$ integers, the $$$i$$$-th should be the answer for the $$$i$$$-th test case.
prob_desc_input_spec: The first line contains one integer $$$t$$$ ($$$1 \le t \le 1000$$$) Â â€” number of test cases. Then $$$t$$$ lines follow, the $$$i$$$-th line contains one integer $$$n$$$ ($$$1 \le n \le 10^9$$$) for the $$$i$$$-th test case.
source_code:
t = int(input())
vet= []
for _ in range(0,t):
    res = 0
    n = int(input())
    if n >=10:
        res = int(n/10)
        n = int(n%10)
    
    if n >=9:
        res +=1
    vet.append(res)
print(*vet, sep='\n')
